channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SPR-2735] Serialization incompatibility between Spring 1.2 and 2.0
item.description:
When using remoting, especially rmi or ejb remoting, all classes will be serialized before sent over the wire. Unfortunately that does not work if client and server are using different versions of Spring jars and if there are some Spring classes involved.

The problem is that Spring does not specify serialVersionUID for serializable classes. That is most critical for ApplicationEvent class and all the exceptions. So, I'd suggest to use serialVersionUID's from Spring 1.2.8 to all serializable classes and from now on always explicitly specify that value.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I agree that we should specify serialVersionUIDs for classes that are actually compatible. Classes whose structure hasn't changed shouldn't be affected in the first place (since the default calculated serialVersionUID should be the same), but of course classes with structural changes and no serialVersionUID specified are indeed affected by this.

That said, note that Spring classes are not actually sent across the wire that often. Most applications will have application-specific remoting facades with application-specific classes in the signature, with Spring "just" being a backend "implementation detail".

I've changed the title of this issue to reflect the serialization compatibility, since "backwards compatibility" usually refers to local updates of the framework jars - which isn't broken here: Everything should work fine if Spring 2.0 is used on both sides of the fence.

Juergen

Jurgen, the problem with remoting it that one may want to update one app, but can't update app on the other end at the same time. That is what happens with me.

Also note, that even if there are no new state, even adding new methods or changing method signatures would change the geenrated serialVersionUID.

First of all, I do see your point. I'm just arguing that it doesn't affect typical applications that much...

Note that we do have serialVersionUIDs specified on Spring's remoting infrastructure classes themselves. So the potential for breakage between Spring 1.2 and 2.0 in remoting scenarios is in the case of Spring classes themselves used as arguments or return values in the application's remote service interfaces. This is not a typical scenario: Most applications rather only have application-specific classes in those service interfaces in the first place. And if they do use Spring classes as remote service arguments, I would strongly recommend using the same Spring version on both sides.

That said, I will add appropriate serialVersionUIDs where necessary. ApplicationEvent is an obvious candidate, as are a couple of specific exception classes; I'm sure there are others as well. However, I'd like to analyze those on a case-by-case basis rather than simply adding 1.2.8's serialVersionUIDs for everything: Some of those classes might be backwards-compatible even with Spring 1.1, while others might have changed in a fashion that is not actually compatible with Spring 1.2 anymore. The to-be-specified serialVersionUIDs need to reflect this.

In any case, thanks for pointing this out!

Juergen

I have added a couple of serialVersionUIDs in central places. To be completed for 2.0.2, including actual interoperation tests.

Juergen

I consider this addressed in 2.0.1 for the time being, since we haven't found any further serialization compatibility issues that would affect typical remoting scenarios.

To be reopened if any remaining issues are discovered.

Juergen
